steps: You bring a new microwave home and discover that you’ve been sold a faulty appliance
A plumber gives you a bill that is higher than you expected
You are reprimanded while other people’s behaviour goes unnoticed
Your car gets stuck in the snow or in the mud
You speak to someone and they don’t respond
Someone claims more than you think they deserve
You are trying to carry your coffee carefully and someone bumps into you
You hang up your clothes in the cloakroom and someone knocks them onto the floor and clumsily tries to pick them up
From the moment you walk into a shop, a salesperson follows you around with constant advice and recommendations
You have arranged to go somewhere with someone, but at the last minute they leave and you end up on your own
People make fun of you and crack jokes at your expense
Your car stalls at a traffic light and the driver in the car behind starts shouting and swearing at you
You awkwardly manoeuvre while turning around in a car park and, as you look out of the window, you hear someone say: “Where did you learn to drive?”
Someone makes a mistake and blames it on you
You are trying to concentrate and the person sitting next to you keeps jiggling their legs
You lend someone something important and they don’t return it
Nothing has gone according to plan all day, and then someone tells you that you haven’t done what you agreed to do
You are trying to discuss something important with a friend, but they keep getting distracted and joking
You find yourself arguing with someone who is clearly very incompetent
Someone keeps interfering in an argument that has nothing to do with them
You are in a real hurry, and the person walking in front of you is moving slowly and won’t let you pass
You step on a sticky piece of chewing gum
The elderly women sitting outside your building keep talking about you
While rushing somewhere, you tear your trousers on a sharp object
The ATM swallows your card

0.text: Studies show that people who practise “cognitive reappraisal” — that is, trying to see a situation in a more constructive or positive light — experience less stress and irritation in situations like these.
0.fact: Psychologists recommend taking a deep breath and briefly thinking about the long-term consequences in moments like this. It helps reduce stress and makes it easier to make a more rational decision.

1.text: Research shows that unexpected expenses are among the strongest triggers of stress and irritation for most people.
1.fact: There is a phenomenon known as the “price anchor”, when people form expectations about the cost of a service based on previous experience or incomplete information. This often leads to disappointment when they are faced with the actual price.

2.text: Practising mindfulness can help you cope with feelings of unfairness. Studies show that people who meditate regularly cope more easily with situations like this.
2.fact: In Japanese culture, there is the concept of “wa” (harmony), which encourages people to avoid open confrontation and remain calm even in unfair situations in order to preserve social harmony.

3.text: Psychologists point out that feeling helpless in situations like this can quickly turn into irritation. Taking active steps to solve the problem, however, can trigger the release of endorphins, which improves your mood.

4.text: Psychologists sometimes refer to being ignored as a kind of “social death”. Research shows that the brain reacts to social exclusion in much the same way as to physical pain.

5.text: Psychologists call this phenomenon the “illusion of superiority” or the Dunning–Kruger effect. People with low competence in a given area often overestimate their abilities.

6.text: Mindfulness practice can help you regain your calm more quickly in moments like this. Studies show that regular meditation improves control over emotional reactions.

7.text: Psychologists note that our reaction to situations like this is often linked to “territorial behaviour” — an instinctive desire to protect our belongings and personal space.
7.fact: Anger-management experts often recommend the “STOP” technique in such situations: Stop, Take a breath, Observe what is happening, and only then Proceed.

8.text: Psychologists call this “reactance”: the more strongly someone pushes us, the more we tend to resist, even if what they are offering could be useful.
8.fact: According to a study carried out in the US, about 68% of customers leave a shop because of pushy or intrusive sales staff.

9.text: In some cultures, for example in parts of Latin America, cancelling plans at the last minute is seen as less serious than in Northern Europe or North America. This reflects different attitudes to time and commitments.
9.fact: Studies show that with the development of technology and social media, people have started cancelling plans at the last minute more often, simply because it has become technically easier to do so.

10.text: Psychologists note that teasing and mockery can be perceived by the brain as a form of social threat, activating similar areas to those involved in physical danger.
10.fact: Conflict-management experts recommend using “disarming phrases” — calm responses that reduce tension and deprive the joker of the reaction they are looking for.

11.text: Psychologists refer to this kind of behaviour on the road as “road rage”. Studies show that around 80% of drivers experience intense anger while driving at least once a year.
11.fact: The “fundamental attribution error” leads us to explain other people’s behaviour by their personality traits, while we explain our own behaviour by circumstances. This can intensify negative perceptions of aggressive drivers.

12.text: Research shows that people often behave more aggressively in anonymous situations such as driving, where they feel protected by their car.

13.text: A study in corporate settings found that around 4% of employees regularly shift the blame for their own mistakes onto colleagues.

14.text: Psychologists describe a heightened sensitivity to repetitive sounds or movements as “misophonia”. For some people this can provoke intense irritation and even anger.
14.fact: Albert Einstein often worked in noisy cafés, saying that background noise helped him concentrate. This shows how differently people can react to the same external stimuli.

15.text: Psychologists call this a “violation of reciprocity”. It can trigger a strong sense of unfairness, because it breaks a basic social rule of mutual exchange.

16.text: The “negativity effect” shows that negative events have a stronger impact on our psychological state than positive ones. This helps explain why a bad day can feel particularly heavy.

17.text: The context of a conversation plays a major role in how jokes are perceived. If the topic is serious and emotionally important, jokes can feel especially irritating because they are experienced as a lack of respect for the issue.

18.text: The ability to show empathy can help reduce irritation during a disagreement. Realising that the other person may not be aware of their lack of competence or may simply have limited knowledge can change the way you see them and how you react.

19.text: According to a study conducted at Harvard University, 70% of participants reported that third-party interference in their arguments often made the conflict worse.

20.text: When we are in a hurry, we often experience a sense of urgency that increases irritation. This state is associated with an adrenaline surge, which speeds up the heartbeat and raises stress levels.
20.fact: In psychology there is a concept called “blocking”, when something or someone gets in the way of what we intend to do or where we want to go. This creates frustration, especially when we feel under time pressure.

21.text: Stepping on chewing gum often triggers disgust, which is one of the basic human emotions. It is a natural reaction to potentially harmful or unpleasant substances that evolved as a way of protecting our health.
21.fact: According to a survey by the British research agency YouGov, around 70% of people feel annoyed or disgusted when they step on chewing gum.

22.text: Knowing that you are being watched and talked about can heighten anxiety and stress. This is linked to the “observer effect”, where people change their behaviour when they know they are being observed.
22.fact: Princess Diana was frequently the subject of gossip and public scrutiny. She learned to ignore much of the negative attention and focus on her charitable work, which helped her maintain inner calm and confidence.

23.text: Small mishaps like this can seriously affect our mood. Unexpected negative events disrupt our sense of control and predictability, which triggers stress and irritation.
23.fact: The so-called “Broken Glass effect” describes how minor annoyances can build up and amplify our negative perception. If you are already in a rush and stressed, torn trousers can feel like “the last straw” that greatly intensifies your irritation.

24.text: When something like this happens, it can create a strong sense of losing control, which increases stress and irritation. We are used to relying on technology, and when it fails us, it shakes our feeling of safety and predictability.

normal.text: Your level of irritability is within the normal range. As a rule, you manage to stay calm and respond to life’s situations in a balanced way.
normal.title: Normal state

light.text: At times you may feel mildly irritated, but it does not really disrupt your usual rhythm of life. Overall, you are able to keep your composure and deal with stressful situations in a constructive way.
light.title: Mild irritability

severe.text: From time to time you experience increased irritability, and certain situations can cause emotional discomfort. This is a fairly common state, especially when you are under high pressure or living at a fast pace. Small practices of rest and relaxation can help you maintain emotional balance.
severe.title: Moderate irritability

hard.text: You may often feel irritated, and small things can noticeably affect your mood. This may be a sign of accumulated tension or fatigue. It is worth paying attention to your emotional state and thinking about ways to take care of yourself and restore your resources.
hard.title: Increased irritability

extreme.text: Irritation may accompany you for a large part of the day and significantly affect how you feel. This condition can be emotionally draining. Support from a specialist or working with stress-management techniques can help improve your wellbeing and bring back a sense of control and calm.
extreme.title: Pronounced irritability

text: How often do you find yourself feeling irritated, and how much does it affect your life? This test is based on the Novaco Anger Scale and has been adapted to assess irritability as a milder form of emotional tension.

This tool can help you understand how often you experience irritation, what tends to trigger it, and how you usually respond. It can be an important step toward understanding your emotions better and strengthening your emotional resilience.
